section.title: Referencing alternative identifiers: expressing equivalence
section.para: Vocabularies used in this section:
Linked Open Data in general, and the Research & Education Space in particular, is at its most useful when the data describing things links to other data describing the same thing.
In RDF, this is achieved using the owl:sameAs predicate. This predicate implies a direct equivalence relationship—in effect, it creates a synonym.
You can use owl:sameAs whether or not the alternative identifiers use http: or https:, although the usefulness of URIs which aren't resolveable is limited.

note.para: Take care when using owl:sameAs to ensure that the subject and the object really are directly equivalent. In particular, make sure that you don’t accidentally state that somebody’s description of something (be it an HTML page or some other serialisation) is the same as the thing being described.

section.title: Metadata describing rights and licensing
section.para: Vocabularies used in this section:

The data describing digital assets (including RDF representations themselves) must be made available under the terms of a supported license and include explicit licensing data in order for it to be indexed by the Research & Education Space and be useable by applications. Our approach is aligned with the Open Data Institute’s guide to publishing machine-readable rights data.

section.title: Incorporating rights information into RDF data
section.para: In many cases, the simplest way of expressing rights information is to include it in the data that you're publishing, and this can often be accomplished by adding a single triple to each avaialble resource:

The above example assumes that you do not set @base to be anything other than the document’s own URI. If you do, you will need to be more specific in the subject of your licensing triple. It is important that the subject of this triple is the URI of the actual concrete document. If you have different URIs for each RDF representation, and either send a Content-Location header or redirect to them, you need to ensure that the subject of the licensing triple is representation-specific URI (e.g., /books/9781899066100.ttl).

tip.para: The Research & Education Space crawler is stateless, like the underlying HTTP protocol itself. In practice, this means that when a document is being processed by the crawler, the only information which can be used to evaluate it is the request-URI, the Content-Location (if provided), any Link headers that were sent, and the serialised RDF itself.

Most importantly, you cannot assume when you write your RDF that the crawler (or any other HTTP client) will be aware of alternative URIs which redirect to your document (for example, via a 303 See Other redirect), and so although you can include triples about those URIs in the document, they will have no role in determining whether the licensing is suitable for use in the Research & Education Space.

If you need to, you can provide more information than the license triple alone. For example, you might include a request which is not a formal requirement of the licensing terms, but you would like consumers to adhere to if possible.

One way to do this is to include a dct:license triple referring to the well-known license URI, alongisde a dct:rights triple pointing to a locally-defined odrs:RightsStatement entity (described using the Open Data Rights Statement Vocabulary).

section.title: Expressing rights information using the Link HTTP header
section.para: It’s possible to express licensing information using the Link HTTP response header. To do so, simply send a Link header pointing to one of the well-known license URIs listed below and rel="license".

note.para: The Research & Education Space crawler translates Link headers into RDF triples while evaluating resources it has retrieved. Unless the header specifies otherwise, the subject is the URI considered to be that of the document (which is the Content-Location if specified, or the request-URI otherwise), the predicate is the rel value interpreted as a URI against a base of http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml/vocab# (in other words, license is interpreted as http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml/vocab#license, while a fully-qualified URI will be used as-is), and the object is the link target (in the example above, http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/).

section.title: Describing conditionally-accessible resources
section.para: Vocabularies used in this section:

Many kinds of digital asset are not available to the general public but may be accessed by the RES audience: students and teachers affiliated with a recognised educational institution in the UK. This may be because specific exceptions in law allow access when it would not otherwise be possible, or because the rights-holder has elected to make the assets available only to those in education.

In order to support this, and ensure that users of RES applications are able to use to the greatest range of material that they legitimately have access to, the metadata describing those assets which aren’t available to the public but are to educational users must describe means by which they are accessed.

tip.para: A given asset may be available from multiple sources, each with its own specific constraints applied to who may access it. For example, a recording of a radio programme might be held on behalf of educational users by two separate online services, both requiring that the affiliated institution be a licensee of the relevant ERA licensing scheme, and both operating their own institutional-level subscription schemes. To be most useful, the RES index must aggregate the metadata describing both means of access, and the metadata must convey sufficient information so as to allow applications to decide which, if any, should be presented to the end-user.
